COOK FOR GOOD

We had the most exhilarating, heartwarming time working with the team @cookforgood.uk yesterday 

@karenmattison_cookforgood and @robinne_cookforgood have set up one of the most impressive food charities I've had the pleasure of working with, in the heart of a Kings Cross estate.  Although a stone's throw away from Hoppers Kings Cross, this part of KX couldn't be a more different world. CFG runs a social pantry, cooking school and many more amazing initiatives to integrate members of the local community, giving them dignity and confidence through working and learning in the kitchen. 

Last night's supper club had an unbelievable turnout of both volunteers and guests from homes and businesses around KX and further. I know I will be back in that kitchen many many times in the future, and encourage you to read more and support the great work these ladies are doing. 

A massive thank you from @renjithsarathchandran @kavindakumarage and team @hopperslondon for inviting us to host this very very special evening and making us feel so welcome in your kitchen ❤️

#kingscross #pantry #socialenterprise #charity #cookforgood #hopperslondon #karangokani

THE INDIAN BREAD RECIPE SERIES (DROPS TOMORROW)

Over the next few weeks I'm going to be sharing some of my favourite Indian bread recipes for you to make at home. So follow @karancooks and stock up on atta, flour, spices, pickles, potatoes because we are going to be cooking a ton....

What rotis/breads do you want to make? 

#karangokani #karancooks #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #roti #bread #naan #paratha #instadaily #eats

🇮🇳INDIAN BREADS EP 1: FULKA/ROTLI/ROTI/CHAPATTI (OR BALLOON BREAD!) 🎈

TIPS AND INGREDIENTS ⬇️

The simple basic Indian chapatti is a staple in homes across the country, and in ours here in London. It still excites me so much watching it balloon up at the end. 

The full method is in the video but top tips are:

1. Use whole wheat chakki, roti, Indian bread atta or flour. This is now readily available in most supermarkets or online. It's very difficult to get the rotis as soft and puffy without it. 

2. Make sure your dough is not too sticky and yet not too dry. The puff is linked to the correct hydration (aka moisture level) of the dough. I aim for about 75-80% hydration (in bakers speak!). This also means cooking it correctly and just enough on the dry pan so that the outside sets, but the inside remains moist and creates water vapour when heated up on the direct flame. 

3. Resting is essential, both to autolyse the flour and relax the gluten. But the good news is, unlike a lot of doughs this doesn't need a ton of rest and can be made from start to finish in a little over an hour.

4. Roll the roti using enough dry flour to make it easy for you, as most of this will fall off when you dust it before cooking. It's essential not to have too many kinks and crevices in the roti or the steam will escape and it won't puff up properly.

5. You can store leftover dough in the fridge for up to 2 days. After that, I find it deteriorates, but that's if it ever makes it to day two! 

6. You can cook and store the chapattis wrapped in foil, but top them with a little ghee or oil before wrapping. They never last long enough to make it into my freezer but I'm sure there freeze well. 

Ingredients:

150g atta/chakki flour/chapatti flour
110g warm water (at body temp)
large pinch of salt
1.5 tsp ghee or sunflower/rapeseed oil 
(dry flour to dust) 

#karancooks #karangokani #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #bread #naan #paratha #chapatti #phulka #fulka #indianbread

🇮🇳INDIAN BREADS EP 2: AVOCADO ROTI 🥑

TIPS AND INGREDIENTS ⬇️

We love this bright green avocado and spinach roti at home. It's easy, different, healthy, and absolutely gorgeous to look at. 

The full method is in the video but my top tips are:

1. Watch Episode 1 on the simple roti, as many of the tips and tricks from there apply here equally. 

2. You can swap the spinach for wild garlic or any other blanched green leaf. Skip the avocado if you like and increase the spinach to make up the weight below.

3. Add a green chilli and ginger if you want to add more of a kick to the roti.

4. I find it much harder to get these to puff up than simple rotis, but they are equally tasty even if they don't puff up as well. 

Ingredients:

180g in total blitzed avocado and spinach (with 1clove garlic and a pinch of cumin) 
200g atta/chapatti flour
large pinch of salt
1.5 tsp ghee or sunflower/rapeseed oil 
(dry flour to dust) 

#karancooks #karangokani #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #bread #roti #paratha #chapatti #avocado #spinach #healthy #vegan #indianbread

🇮🇳INDIAN BREADS EP 3: MUNG DAL DOSA

TIPS AND INGREDIENTS ⬇️

This dosa (think Indian pancake/crepe) is an easy, quick and healthy recipe that's great on its own, with some chutney, stuffed, or as a vehicle for your curry. 

The full method is in the video but top tips are:

1. If using any other lentils you'll need to soak them longer. And if you don't have the green mung you can go with all husked (yellow) or vice versa.

2. I like making this on a thick cast iron pan/skillet, but it works equally well on a non stick pan. Make sure the pan, whatever you choose to use, is hot and completely clean/dry when the dosa batter goes down, so it sticks. 

3. Oil is added onto the dosa, think of it as 'reverse frying'! 

5. You can freeze the batter or keep it refrigerated for up to 4 days. 

6. For chutneys or accompaniments go get my book Hoppers: The Cookbook @hopperslondon 🙏

Ingredients:

75g yellow husked mung dal
75g green split mung dal 
1/2 tsp fenugreek (methi) seeds 
1 tbsp rice flour (ground rice)
1 tbsp fine semolina 
Large pinch asafoetida 
1/2 tsp turmeric
1 tsp cumin 
1 green chilli (optional) 
1 inch root ginger 1 inch 
Salt to taste 

#karancooks #karangokani #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #bread #mung #crepe #pancakes #dosa #chilla #indianbread

🇮🇳INDIAN BREADS EP 4: SIMPLE PUNJABI PARATHA 

Follow me @karancooks for similar recipes and a whole lot more coming up soon....

TIPS AND INGREDIENTS ⬇️

This basic Punjabi paratha is the basis for many more exciting stuffed, coiled, wrapped parathas and breads, but is brilliant in itself. So I suggest getting to grips with this dough before going on to make the more complicated versions I'll be dropping over the next few weeks. Stay tuned!

The full method is in the video but my top tips are:

1. Use whole wheat chakki, roti, Indian bread atta or flour. This is now readily available in most supermarkets or online.

2. Make sure your dough is not too sticky and yet not too dry. 

3. Resting is essential, both to autolyse the flour and relax the gluten. But the good news is, unlike a lot of doughs this doesn't need a ton of rest and can be made from start to finish in a little over an hour.

4. This dough should be a little less sticky and firmer than the plain fulka/chapatti dough we made in Episode 1, and a lot easier to handle. 

5. You can store leftover dough in the fridge for up to 2 days. 

6. You can cook and store the parathas wrapped in foil, but top them with a little ghee or oil before wrapping. They will be fine at room temp for a day, in the fridge for up to 3 days, and freeze wonderfully too. Warm with a splash of water on a pan over medium heat or microwave for 30 seconds wrapped in a damp tea towel. 

Ingredients:

250g chapatti flour, atta or chakki atta 
180g water
Pinch of salt
1 tbsp ghee

Lots of ghee to cook and layer!
1 tbsp Carom seeds (ajwain) (optional) 

#karangokani #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #bread #punjabi #paratha #roti #indianbread

🇮🇳INDIAN BREADS EP 5: MINT LACHCHA PARATHA 🌿

Follow me @karancooks for similar recipes and a whole lot more coming up soon....

This is one of my favourite parathas. Beautifully bright and herby, a great summer bread, you're going to love it! All it needs is a light Dal on the side. 

The full method is in the reel, but you will need to watch Episode 4: Punjabi Paratha for the basic paratha dough recipe. We use the same basic dough recipe here.

1.5 tbsp chopped mint, per paratha
Large pinch kasoori methi (dried fenugreek leaves), per paratha

#karangokani #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #bread #mint #pudina #paratha #roti #chapatti #indianbread

WOOD AND COAL FIRED CALIFORNIA STYLE PIZZA 🔥🔥🍕🍕🍕🇺🇸 

Puffy Neapolitan pizzas get a lot of airtime, but this is one of my favourite styles, with a crunchy (yet airy) crust, crisp base, little bit of colour, oregano and garlic infused tomato sauce and a ton of cheese. I've channeled @nancysilverton @pizzeriamozzalondon to create something very similar in my @gozney #gozneydome in the backyard...

Here are some tips and tricks for all you pizza geeks out there. Feel free to DM me or comment below if you've got any more Q's:

1. I use a mix of 60:40 Caputo pizzeria flour and @waitrose Strong Bread flour and used @mike_fitzick recipe on gozney.com 

https://www.gozney.com/blogs/recipes/cheese-pizza-recipe

2. I add dried oregano, grated garlic, a touch of sugar and salt to my passata.

3. Using a mix of wood, lumpwood or briquettes I run the dome at 310-350c. The coal helps keep the heat consistent without too high a flame that allows this pizza to cook longer and slower than a Neopolitan pie. 

4. I use a 30:70 mix of fine semolina and flour to dust and stretch out the base. The semolina clings on for that amazing texture and crunch.

5. I cook the pie with all the toppings but NO cheese for 3 minutes. Then remove, brush the edges with olive oil, load with a mix of fresh mozz, compressed mozz, cheddar and red Leicester cheese (anyone know a good American cheese in the UK?), and cook for a further 3 minutes or thereabouts. 

That's it! What's your favourite style of pizza?

#karangokani #gozney #cookdifferent #nycpizza #pizza #california #recipes

INDIAN BREADS EPISODE 6: ACHARI (PICKLE) PARATHA 🌶️🌶️🌶️🇮🇳

Follow me @karancooks for similar recipes and a whole lot more coming up soon....

Another day, another paratha, this one's packed with flavour and dead easy to make. Also a great way to use up that jar of pickle lying at the back of the shelf. Get a big bowl of chilled yoghurt to dip these into and you'll need very little else....

The full method is in this video, but you will need to go back to Episode 4 for the basic paratha dough recipe before you start. We use the same basic dough recipe here. 

Ingredients:

Basic paratha dough (see Indian Breads Ep 4) 
1/2 tsp ghee, per paratha (plus more to cook) 
1 tbsp of your favourite pickle (I like green chilli, lime or stoneless mango), per paratha
Pinch each of dried fenugreek leaves (kasoori methi), carom seeds (ajwain), nigella seeds (kalonji) per paratha

#karangokani #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #bread #achar #pickles #paratha #chapatti #indianbread

INDIAN BREADS EPISODE 7: RUMALI ROTI 🇮🇳

Follow me @karancooks for similar recipes and a whole lot more coming up soon....

If there's one bread I could eat with every meal, it would be this! Rumali Roti which translates literally as handkerchief bread is the thinnest, most delicate bread you will make/eat. With a little bit of practice it's not as hard as it look. I hope you give this one a go at home. PS: make sure you've got some black dal to dip into.....

Watch the video for the full recipe, the Ingredients are below: 

250g plain flour
50 cold milk
100 cool water 
2g salt
15g oil

#karangokani #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #bread #roomaliroti #rumali #roti #chapatti #indianbread

DIRTY BBQ TIPS AND TRICKS

It's finally (kind of) BBQ season and here's one of my favourite ways of cooking corn for that perfect char, yet juicy kernels - COOKING THEM STRAIGHT ON THE COALS AKA COOKING THEM DIRTY

This method is also amazing for other veg, some steaks and anything that needs a quick and high cook. But here's a few things to remember:

1. Only use all natural coal (no briquettes or quick light stuff).
2. When cooking steaks or meat, cook on embers, once the flames have died down. For corn or quick charred veg I like a little lick of fire. 
3. Ensure you have a flat bed of glistening coal before you place your food down on it. This cuts down the oxygen supply and prevents flare ups or food burning. So effectively what you're doing is cooking with the residual heat of the coals and no fire. It seems counterintuitive but you won't burn your food or see massive flames if you cook this way. 
4. Avoid cooking very fatty steaks dirty. Or render them fully over indirect heat and finish on coals for a golden crust. 

DO YOU COOK DIRTY? 

#bbq #cookingtips #hacks #recipes #grilling #corn #steak #dirtysteak #charcoal #karangokani

INDIAN BREADS EPISODE 8: STOVETOP NAAN🇮🇳🫓

Possibly the most famous Indian bread. This is how I've cooked it for years at home to mimic the char and high heat you get in a tandoor. 

TIP: If you've not got a gas hob at home you can start cooking on the induction and finish by placing the pan under the grill in your oven. 

Watch the video for the full recipe, ingredients below: 

300g plain white (all purpose) flour
1/4 tsp baking soda 
1/2 tsp baking powder 
1/2 tsp sugar 
1/2 tsp salt 
1g or a large pinch of instant yeast
50g (2 tbsp) Greek yogurt 
15g (1 tbsp) oil 
100g milk (or a little more, as required) 

Follow me @karancooks for many more recipes like this and hit me up if you've got any questions. Enjoy!

Sri Lankan cuisine is on today's menu✨🍽️✨

Hoppers, which accompany many curries, are a traditional bread made with short-grain rice that's soaked with coconut then ground and fermented with yeast. Karan Gokani explains how the batter is fermented like a sourdough then swirled around an aluminum wok over a gas burner, creating a bowlike pancake to accompany curries and sambals.

@karancooks shares his recipe with us and chats with @kcrwevan about "Hoppers," his new cookbook inspired by his London restaurant @hopperslondon 

🔗 Get at the link in bio to get the recipe and hear the convo.

🇮🇳INDIAN BREADS EPISODE 8: SINDHI KOKI 🌶️🌰🌿

We grew up eating Sindhi kokis at home in Mumbai. There are many different recipes for this, some with fewer spices; and others with a lot more ghee. This is my adaption of the classic recipe, and I often eat it as a snack with a bowl of chilled greek yoghurt! 

Feel free to substitute or omit some of the spices if you like or add more ghee to the dough for a softer and richer texture. I like it crisp and almost biscuity on the outside with a moist crumb and all the lovely flavour from the charred onions, chillies and seeds. 

Watch the video for the full recipe, ingredients below: 

200g wholewheat or chapatti flour (atta)
150g water 
1/4 chopped red onion
1/2 tsp pomegranate seeds (anardana)
1/2 tsp coriander seeds
1/2 tsp cumin seeds 
1/2 tsp chopped fresh coriander 
1/4 tsp chopped green chilli (optional)
1/4 tsp salt 
20g ghee, plus more to cook the kokis

🇮🇳INDIAN BREADS EPISODE 10: DOSA 🔥🔥🔥

This one's probably one of the most loved breakfast staples in South India and there are many ways to make the batter. I've got an exhaustive recipe in Hoppers: The Cookbook (available online and in store in most parts of the world, I hope!). In this video I want to show you the difference between making dosas on a non stick pan Vs an iron skillet. You can get these skillets at a lot of South Asian stores or if you're in the UK, @nethertonfoundry do a great version that will last forever. 

200g parboiled/idli rice
50g raw husked black lentils 
25g daria dal
1/2 tsp fenugreek seeds
1/2 tsp salt 
Oil or ghee to cook 

Soak the lentils and fenugreek seeds overnight (5-6 hours minimum). Then grind them to the consistency of a thick gritty cake batter, adding a little water at a time along with the other ingredients. Now allow it all to ferment overnight for 10 to 12 hours until you see little bubbles on top and it has a sour smell like yoghurt. 

At this stage you could cook your dosa or store the batter in the fridge for up to 4 days or in the freezer until you need it. 

The video shows you the consistency that you want the final batter and how to cook it on both a non-stick and cast iron pan. 

PS: you can find really good, frozen or chilled batter at a lot of South Asian stores or else just pop into your local @hopperslondon and order a dosa! 

#karangokani #indianfood #indianrecipes #easyrecipes #bread #naan #paratha #dosa #roti #chapatti #indianbread

Jowar or Sorgam Rotis are naturally gluten free and are one of the healthiest Indian breads. 

They are also a great sub for wheat or corn tortillas and perfect for taco night 🌮

Watch the video for the full recipe, ingredients below: 

200g water 
100g jowar
1/2 tsp Salt
1 tsp ghee or veg oil if you want to make these dairy free

OG BUTTER CHICKEN

After weeks of the most unpredictable weather in London I decided to give my BBQ a bit of a deep clean and cook one of my favourite recipes. This butter chicken recipe is like none you've had before, there isn't a tomato in sight and the sauce is pure butter, cream and smokiness! 

Thanks to the magic @brillo_clean XL pads I had the grill shining in less than 15 minutes. The pads work wonders on smoke stains and gritty burnt bits. Just make sure you wash and wipe it all down with a clean sponge once you've scrubbed off the grime. 

Now on to the recipe, I've got the whole process in the video, here are the ingredients: 

Marinade:
1 tbsp ginger paste
1 tbsp garlic paste
1 tsp kasoori methi
1 tsp white pepper
1 tbsp tandoori masala
1/3 cup yoghurt
1 tbsp cream cheese 
1.5 tbsp melted butter 
½ tsp turmeric
½ tsp salt
Juice of ½ lime

Kebab Masala:
½ tsp black pepper
½ tsp kasoori methi
1 tsp chaat masala 

Garnish: 
½ cup single cream
⅓ cup melted salted butter 
1 tbsp chopped coriander 
Large pinch Kebab Masala 
½ tsp salt 
Onion rings (optional)

ENJOY!

PRESERVING TOMATOES: SUPER EASY SPICY HOMEMADE PASSATA 🍅🍅🍅🌶️

Why do good canned tomatoes always make the best sauces? 

Apart from being made from some of the ripest and juiciest tomatoes, they are also cooked down and concentrated for a much stronger flavour. I didn't have a tomato mill at home but used this super simple method to make a passata from my home grown San Marzano tomatoes. It will be good for a few weeks and perfect in pastas, on toast, in sauces and even curries. Check out my earlier reel on how to ripen tomatoes perfectly at home if you've got some that are still green or hard. 

Passata Recipe:

1. Cut a little X at the bottom of each tomato and place them in a large bowl. Submerge them in boiling water out of a kettle and leave for 5 minutes. Then drain the water and peel off the skin.

2. Now cut each tomato in half and remove most of the seeds and water from within. 

3. Place the tomatoes in a large saucepan and cook on low heat for 30-45 mins until jammy. I add 2 tbsp olive oil, a splash of sherry vinegar (because these tomatoes were super sweet), tsp of sea salt and some Kashmiri chilli powder at the end. You can also add herbs, pepper or garlic if you like, or just leave it as is. Cook for a final couple of minutes. 

4. Pour it into clean glass jars (that are straight out of the dishwasher, or sterilise them in hot water if you can bother too) while still piping hot and seal them. Once cool, refrigerate the jars and they should be good to go for a few weeks (if they last that long).

FERMENTED SCOTCH BONNET HOT SAUCE 🌶️🍑💥💥💥

A few weeks ago I posted a story asking what you would do with yellow scotch bonnets and the resounding response was 'make a fermented hot sauce'. So here you have my fruity homemade fermented scotch bonnet hot sauce:

For the ferment:

1 cup yellow scotch bonnets, destemmed and deseeded
1/2 a red pepper, destemmed and deseeded
1 ripe peach, stone removed
(2% weight of all of the above, good fine sea salt)

Mix all together and place in a zip lock bag or airtight jar. Leave it in a warm dark cupboard for about 7-10 days, popping the jar or bag open to remove any carbon dioxide produced as a result of the fermentation. You can see I used a vacuum bag and it popped up like a balloon after 7 days. Keep tasting the ferment and when you're happy with it, proceed to making the sauce. NOTE: you can just blitz and use it as it is at this stage if you like. It's terrific!

Hot sauce:

Fermented fruits and all the liquid from the above 
1 cup fresh yellow scotch bonnets, destemmed and deseeded
3 banana chillis or Hungarian peppers, destemmed and deseeded
1 clove garlic, peeled 
1 litre pineapple juice, boiled and reduced to about 100ml 
1/2 tsp xantham gum (optional)
Splash of water and apple cider vinegar
Salt, to your taste 

Mix the fresh chillies, garlic and a splash of water and cook down for about 15 minutes. Once soft, add the fermented chillies and pineapple juice and cook on low heat for 8-10 minutes. 

Then add vinegar and salt to taste, and the xantham if you're using it. Blitz on max for a couple of minutes until smooth. Add more water if you like it thinner, bottle and store in the fridge, or share with friends...

Enjoy!

Adding potatoes to biryani is a very controversial topic back in India and the results can be very polarising! Read on for a little hack that can turn even the most ardent anti-potato biryani cook. 

1. Use Maris Pipers or any good chip potato for this. 

2. Medium or small potatoes are best. 

3. Peel and slice the potatoes really thin, then coat generously in ghee or oil on both sides and layer the bottom of your biryani pan or pot. A heavy well seasoned cast iron pot or non-stick is best if trying this at home. I use an anodised @procookuk pan, which works really well. 

4. Pour some more ghee or oil over your potatoes and then layer your rice and meat over as per the recipe. Garnish, cover and cook on high heat for 5 minutes followed by low heat for the rest of the time required for your biryani. Finish on high heat for 3 minutes to crisp up the potatoes. Serve immediately. 

You can use any layered biryani recipe for this, just make sure you cook on high heat at the beginning and end (step 5 above). The potato slices at the bottom catch all the fat that usually drips to the bottom of the pan and turn into these beautiful crisps packed with flavour. 

Clearly I'm a fan of potatoes in my biryani, are you?

SPICY YELLOW TOMATO KETCHUP

This easy ketchup recipe is a great homemade substitute for the store bought stuff, so much healthier, tastier and all natural...

For the ferment: 

500g ripe yellow tomatoes
15g sea salt (3% weight of the tomatoes) 

For the ketchup:

Fermented tomatoes from above
75g apple cider vinegar
60g honey/kithul treacle/maple syrup or 50g sugar 
1/2 tsp garlic granules
1/2 tsp onion powder
1/4 tsp ground coriander 
Pinch of cinnamon
1/4 tsp mustard powder 
1/4 tsp white pepper powder 
1/4 tsp unroasted Sri Lankan curry powder (optional)
Salt, to taste 

Mix the tomatoes and salt together and crush them up slightly. Pack them in a strong zip lock bag removing as much air as possible. Leave in a warm place to ferment for a week or two. I used a vacuum sealed bag for this but you could use a jar too. If using a jar, you'll need to pop it open to release the carbon dioxide build up from time to time, this is not required for a vacuum setup. 

Once you're happy with the flavour of your ferment, blend the tomatoes with all the other ingredients and cook it down till glossy and thick. This will continue to thicken when cool. Pour into a jar and store in the fridge. This should be good to go for a few months, but it probably won't last that long. 

Note: you can use red tomatoes instead of yellow and freestyle with the ingredients as much as you like. The list above is a rough guide to the version I love, but keep tasting as you go along and skip, substitute or add more of an ingredient if you like. 

PS: this is a great one for the kids if you avoid the spices.

Let's talk about OKRA (AKA Ladies' Fingers, Bhindi, Vendai, Bandakka, and more). It's my absolute favorite vegetable, but I get it - the sliminess can be a turnoff. Here's a nifty trick to make chopping and cooking okra a breeze next time.

**PRO TIP** Instead of using the edge of the knife, opt for the tip when chopping okra. This simple change prevents it from sticking to the knife, allowing you to slice through it in half the time.

**BONUS TIP** Ensure your okra is thoroughly dried before you start cutting and cooking to minimize the slime. Also, when cooking, resist the urge to cover the pan or stir too frequently. Even if it starts off a bit slimy, fear not - it will dry out as it cooks....

Okra can be delicious and hassle-free with these little tricks up your sleeve. And if you're stuck for recipes, the @hopperslondon cookbook has some good ones in there. 🌿🔪✨"

INDIAN GREEN CHILLI PICKLE 🇮🇳🌶️💥

This simple chilli pickle is my go to most nights of the week. Packed with flavour, yet quite light and refreshing. 

The best bit? You can whip it up in just a matter of minutes using a bag of fresh chillies, a few spices and store cupboard essentials. I often like to mix and match the chillies I've grown in my backyard for an extra personal touch.

**Ingredients:**

- 300g mixed green chillies

- 100g rapeseed oil (or any other neutral oil, not olive) 

- 50-70g apple cider vinegar (I've used @willysacv fire cider vinegar)

- 5g each of yellow mustard, black mustard, fenugreek seeds, fennel seeds, and cumin seeds (adjust quantities to your liking)

- 20g sea salt

- 1/2 tsp turmeric (@diasporaco does this better than anyone I know)

Check out the detailed instructions in the video. 

PS: you can eat this immediately, but it's a lot better after a week or two and can happily live in the fridge for 6 months (if it lasts that long...)

Enjoy! 🌶️🍴✨

SPICY HALLOWEEN: SRI LANKAN ROAST PUMPKIN CURRY 🎃🍁🌶️

Here's one of my favourite curries that's perfect for Halloween, autumn or anytime of year really. 

It's inspired by a curry we've had on the @hopperslondon menu, but roasting the pumpkin brings out all its beautiful flavours and there's no need to peel it. It's also vegan, and relatively quick to cook (once you've gathered your ingredients!). Feel free to sub out any of the ingredients you don't like or have.

1/4 pumpkin (or squash), cut into wedges

2+1 tbsp coconut oil 

1+1 tbsp roasted Sri Lankan curry powder (or Madras curry powder)

1+1 tbsp mild red chilli powder, divided

1/4 + 1/4 tsp turmeric, divided 

1/4 tsp fenugreek seeds

1/4 tsp mustard seeds

4 green cardamom pods

1 stick Sri Lankan cinnamon

3 cloves

1 small red onion, chopped 

2 stalks curry leaves

2/3 cup thick coconut milk (first extraction)

Sea salt, to taste

Chilli oil, to garnish 

Enjoy!

CHILLI SMOKED CASHEW NUTS

One of the simplest yet tastiest ways to cook cashews. There's so much oil in the nuts they start to smoke and take on a beautiful flavour when cooked directly over live fire. Then hit them with spices and continue to toast gently at a lower heat until crisp. 

I cooked these at a collaboration dinner with @niklasekstedt and we both ate our body weight in them! I hope you enjoy them as much as we did....

HOMEMADE NUTELLA (WITH A FEW TWISTS)

The kids love this, I love it, and it's so much better for you than the store bought version. You're going to want to make a big batch of it, as it makes for a great gift and stocking filler. 

350g toasted unsalted and peeled hazelnuts
75g cocoa nibs
25g coconut oil 
100-150 kithul treacle (maple, agave or honey) 
1.5 tbsp cocoa powder
Large pinch of salt

Blend everything in a high powered food processor on the highest setting. After about 6 minutes it might look crumbly and dry, but keep processing. At about 10-12 minutes it should magically turn into a silky, smooth, shiny paste. 

Enjoy!

SPAGHETTI WITH MUSSELS AND CHILLI

I love this super easy and quick dish feat. the very underrated mussels! They are so easy to find now at most supermarkets and fishmongers. Make sure you're using live mussels (not cooked) and discard any that were open before cooking or don't open after. 

I used fresh red chillies from the garden, dried Italian chilli flakes and smoked paprika powder, but Kashmiri chilli, Ancho, etc all are their uniqueness to the dish. Freestyle with whatever you have at hand/like. 

Ingredients 

Spaghetti, for two
300g live mussels, cleaned
1 fresh red chilli
1 tsp dried chilli flakes
1 tsp smoked paprika
1 cup white wine
3 cloves garlic 
A handful of ripe cherry tomatoes
Salt, to taste
Good olive oil 

Enjoy! 

#karangokani #easyrecipe #pasta #mussels #chilli #spaghetti #quickmeals #seafood

BRIOCHE AND CAMEMBERT WREATH 

This is one of my favourite party snacks at Christmas time, and can be made in an oven or air fryer. 

Like any bread, you'll need to plan the brioche ahead of time, but the impact this dish always has makes it worth it. Bake it all to order, and I promise it will be gone in half the time it takes to cook. 

While you're at it, make a big batch of that confit garlic, you're going to want to dollop it over everything! 

Ingredients:

Good quality Camembert
Homemade or store bought cranberry sauce
Brioche rolls (see below)
Confit garlic (see below)

For the confit garlic: 

Goose or duck fat (or clarified butter or rapeseed oil for a veggie version)
2 heads garlic
Rosemary 

*Slice the garlic in half and place in an oven proof bowl with the rosemary. 
*Pour over the fat and roast in the oven or air fryer at 180c for 18-25 minutes, until the garlic has gone golden and soft. Allow to come to room temp. 
*You can store this in a jar in the fridge and use it for weeks on potatoes, toast, eggs, etc. 

For the brioche rolls:

350g strong bread flour
30g warm water
50g warm milk
7g dried instant yeast 
2 full large eggs
1 large egg yolk
1 tsp salt
60g sugar
40g melted butter 
White sesame seeds, optional 
Rosemary and Thyme

*In a large mixing bowl mix together the flour, yeast, salt and sugar
*Beat eggs and butter into it. Then add in the milk and water.
*Knead on a low speed for 6 mins or by hand for 10 mins.
*Cover and rest till doubled, about 4-6 hours.

To assemble:

*Grease the sides and base of a round oven proof dish.
*Cut an X into the centre of the cheese and spoon some of the confit garlic and fat into it. Prick a few sprigs of rosemary into the cheese. Place it in the centre of the dish (in it's wooden tub) 
*Roll the dough into small balls and arrange them fairly close to each other around the cheese. Prick a few sprigs of rosemary and thyme between the rolls. 
*Brush the egg yolk over the rolls and sprinkle over sesame seeds. Bake at 165c for 30 mins or until the buns are cooked through and golden on the top. 
*Spoon a dollop of cranberry sauce onto the cheese before serving warm. 

Enjoy 🎅🏽🎄

#christmasrecipes #cheese

CHICKEN CURRY PUFFS 

I grew up eating versions of curry puff - it's the ultimate, versatile, party snack that pleases all generations. 

We've taken this version to the next level using some leftover Hoppers Red Chicken Curry. If you want to stay close to the recipe, you can find the recipe for the curry in the Hoppers Cookbook; but if you're simply looking to repurpose leftovers, any good Sri Lankan, South Indian or Malaysian style curry would do. Equally, a good veggie, fish or meat curry will work brilliantly in these puffs too. 

Ingredients about 6 puffs:

1 large potato, mashed 
1 green chilli, finely chopped 
6-8 curry leaves, finely chopped
1 tbsp Sri Lankan Roasted Curry Powder 
1 cup leftover chicken curry (lamb, fish or vegetarian curries work equally well here) 
Juice of half a lime 
1 pack storebought puff pastry 
Salt, to taste
Eggs, to wash the pastry (you can also use milk if avoiding eggs)
Fennel and cumin seeds, to garnish

In early 2022 we launched Hoppers Feeding the Future alongside HEMAS Outreach Foundation in Sri Lanka. Our goal was to provide vital nutrition and education to the most needy pre-school children across the island 🇱🇰 

Through 2022 we supported 367 children and their families across 15 pre-schools in 6 districts with rations and food. In 2023 we extended our reach to over 1098 families across 33 pre-schools providing them with essential rations and protein packs. 

This year, we also built our first Pre-School in the Kandy district which opened in November and schools 55 children. Our goal is to build at least one more school each year, alongside providing nutritional support to young children across the island.

We thank everyone who’s dined at our restaurants and supported this cause. It’s something very close to all our hearts and we couldn’t be more grateful for all that we’ve been able to achieve so far 🧡

You can find more information about the project and ways to support via the charity page on our website (link in bio).

AIR FRYER CHILLI PANEER NOODLES 🧀🌶️🥡

Here's my twist on the classic Indo-Chinese dish found across street stalls and hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurants across India 🇮🇳

We could never eat enough of this dish growing up in Mumbai. Here's my quick, easy and (relatively) healthy version. I've cooked the paneer in an air fryer and added udon noodles to make it the perfect one bowl/plate meal that's ready in about 15 minutes 🍜

Feel free to skip the noodles and make the chilli paneer as part of a larger spread. I also love it with some fried rice. 

Ingredients, steps and tips below 👇🏽

200g paneer 

For the sauce:
1 tbsp tomato ketchup
1 tsp white vinegar
1 tsp soy sauce 
1 tbsp tomato paste 
1/2 tsp sugar 
Salt, to taste 

To coat the paneer:
2 tbsp cornflour
1/2 tsp turmeric
1/2 tsp cumin powder 
1/2 tsp Kashmiri chilli 
Pinch of salt 
1 tsp vegetable oil 

To stir fry:
1 tbsp vegetable oil
1 tsp each ginger and garlic, minced
1 medium red onion
1/2 green pepper 
2 spring onions 
3-5 green chillies 
100g udon or egg noodles (ready to stir fry)
1 tbsp chilli oil

Soak paneer in boiling water for 15 minutes. Then drain and toss in cornflour, spices, salt and oil. 

Air fry paneer for 10 minutes on 200c. 

Mix all the ingredients for the sauce and add 100ml boiling water. 

In a wok, heat the oil and stir fry the ginger, garlic until aromatic. Then add the onions, peppers and spring onions in. Cook for a couple of minutes and add the sauce and chilli oil in. Check for seasoning. 

Add the noodles to the sauce and stir fry for 2 minutes. Then add the paneer and cook for another minute. 

Serve garnished with spring onions and more chilli oil. 

PS: you can skip the noodles if you prefer, the chilli paneer is a classic and favourite Indo-chinese dish found in streets and restaurants across India. 

I've got some more easy spicy airfryer recipes dropping soon, stay tuned....

SRI LANKAN COCONUT ROTIS 🥥🌴

These simple, quick and rustic Coconut or Pol Rotis are possibly one of my favourite 'breads' from Sri Lanka. 🇱🇰

The mini versions are a perfect base for Christmas canapes. Try them with our Curry Leaf Hummus or Cranberry Seeni Sambol (look back at the grid for both recipes, which were posted in the past couple of weeks). 🍞

Ingredients: 

250g plain white flour (not strong bread flour)

150g fresh or frozen grated coconut (or 100g desiccated coconut, soaked in warm water for 30 minutes)

½ medium red onion, finely chopped

1 green chilli, finely chopped (seeds removed if you prefer it less spicy)

8-10 curry leaves (ideally fresh, or dried), stalk removed and finely chopped

1 tbsp coconut oil

1.5 teaspoon sea salt

Warm water, as required

Tips: 

1. Roll the rotis to the thickness of a couple of pound coins stacked on each other and make sure you cook them in a dry pan. The oil from the coconut and the coconut oil in the dough will ensure they don't go dry. 

2. You want to cook these rotis over a medium to low heat so they cook evenly all the way through. 

3. Serve with your favourite sambol or dip. 

With Xmas and New Year's Eve hot on our heels, what other recipes would you like to watch us cooking over the coming weeks? 🎆🌲🎅🏽

Enjoy! 🙏🏽

PERFECT CRISPY ROAST PORK BELLY 🐷💥🎶

(SOUND ON 🔊)

A crispy skinned Chinese style pork belly takes centre stage (alongside a Peking Goose) at our Xmas table each year 🌲

Although it takes a bit of prep, I've found this trick works wonders to get that perfect crunchy crackling and delicious juicy pork🐖

Here's how I do it:

1. Boil the belly for 10 minutes and then plunge into cold water for another 10. 

2. Marinade the meat in any dry or wet marinade of your choice for 4-6 hours (avoid getting marinade on the skin/top). I've used a char siu paste, five spice and some more. You could go as simple as salt and pepper if you want, it will still be delicious. 🌶️

3. Mix 1/2 tsp baking soda with 1/2 tsp white vinegar and 1/2 tsp salt. Brush a thin layer of this over the skin. Then wrap the sides and base of the meat in foil, leaving just the top/skin exposed and refrigerate overnight. 🖌️

4. Bring the meat out of the fridge an hour before cooking and leave on the counter. Then pour a generous amount of salt to cover the skin, being careful to avoid it getting into your foil parcel. 🧂

5. Roast at 150c for 1.5 hours. Then pull it out and carefully peel off the salt layer. 🍖

6. Now turn on the grill/broiler to 200c and place the belly on the top shelf right under the coil. It should puff up and get perfectly crispy in 15 minutes. Make sure you watch it like a hawk at this stage as it can go from golden to burnt in a matter of minutes. 🦅

7. Rest for 15 minutes and cut up skin side down. I serve this with the juices from the foil parcel and steamed rice. 🍚

If I'm not cooking pork like this, I get it into a curry. How do you cook pork belly? 

Enjoy!

SPICED PANETTONE BREAD & BUTTER PUDDING 🍞🧈🍮

Here's a great little recipe to turn that left over Christmas Panettone and a few basic staples into an incredible dessert, that's far more than the sum of its parts. I like to spice my bread and butter pudding and add some chocolate chips to it for extra richness but feel free to leave these out. 🌲🧈🍞

Finally, if you don't have panettone at home, you can still make this with ordinary sliced white bread, or better still, some stale brioche. Just remember to add about 60-80g of granulated sugar to your egg and milk mix. 🥖🥚🥛

650g panetonne
6 eggs 
500ml whole milk 
150g brandy cream (or double cream)
3 green cardamoms (seeds only) 
1/2 tsp each ground cinnamon and nutmeg (optional)
1 tsp vanilla extract 
Pinch of sea salt 
50g butter
75g brown sugar 
75g white sugar 
Handful of chocolate chips (optional) 
Icing sugar, to dust

Cut up the panettone into chunks and toast it for 10 to 15 minutes. 

Whisk up everything else apart from the chocolate into a custard base.

Make the caramel toffee sauce by melting butter and the sugar in a pan over a medium heat. Keep stirring and make sure it doesn't burn. Then pour it into your baking dish. And tip the bread over. 

Now pour the custard all over and make sure the bread is evenly soaked but don't squash it too much. 

Dot in your chocolate chips. 🍫

Bake at 180c for 25-30 minutes until just set. 

Dust with icing sugar and enjoy hot or cold. 🍮

TRAYBAKE PIZZA FOCACCIA 🍕🍞📥🫧

This is one of the bubbliest doughs I've handled, and while it does need a little bit of practice, results in the best focaccias or deep dish traybake pizzas you will eat once you've got the hang of it. 

If you get started today, you can still make this in time for your NYE party. It's perfect for kids, adults, one, two or many! 

Serves 5-6

Day 1:

Mix together:

1g dried instant yeast

100 strong flour

100 water 

15g honey

Mix and leave covered at room temp for 4-6 hours until bubbly. 

Then mix together:

600 strong flour

350 water

And add in the bubbly premix from earlier. 

Knead well until it all comes together, approx 10-12 mins (or 4-5 minutes in a stand mixer)  

Then Add: 

25g olive oil

12g salt 

40g ice cold water 

Knead for 10-15 minutes until the dough is smooth. Don't worry if it's still a little sticky, you can use some olive oil on your hands to stop it sticking. 

Place the dough in a large tray or bowl and cover. After 30 minutes, oil your hands and pull the edges of the dough up and fold over into the centre. This is called a stretch and fold. Go all the way around the dough, then cover and leave at room temp.

Repeat the stretch and fold a couple of times every 30 mins, and then rest the dough without touching it for another hour and a half. In total the dough should sit at room temp for about 3 hours. Then pop it into the fridge for about 18-24 hours. 

Day 2:

Before baking, bring the dough to room temp for about 2 hours. Stretch and fold one more time and transfer the dough into a heavily oiled metal baking tray. Leave covered for 45 mins. The dough should be very light and bubbly by now. Using the tips of your fingers, poke holes into the dough gently (without ripping the surface) and pour some olive oil all over the surface.

Spread a generous layer of tomato passata on the dough and sprinkle over red peppers and onions. Bake at 210c for 20 mins on the top shelf. 

Then sprinkle over grated mozzeralla, sundried toms, sliced garlic and herbs and bake for 10-15 mins more at 200c. Remove from the oven and rest for 10 mins. 

Garnish with fresh basil and loads of olive oil. 🌿

INDIAN 101: ALOO MATAR 🥔🫛🇮🇳

This simple, quick, yet extremely delicious potato and pea curry is a staple in homes across India, particularly in the north. I love eating it with some steamed Basmati rice drizzled with ghee, or simple rotis (scroll down my feed for some recipe ideas in the Indian Bread Series👇🏻).

4 medium potatoes, peeled and cubed (I used Maris Pipers) 
1 small red onion, finely chopped 
2 bay leaves 
1 tsp each ginger and garlic 
1/2 tin tomatoes
1 tbsp vegetable oil or ghee 
1 tsp cumin seeds 
1 tsp turmeric 
1 tsp red chilli powder
1/2 tsp crushed red chilli
1/2 tsp cumin powder 
3/4 tsp coriander powder 
1 cup peas 
1 tbsp chopped coriander, and more to garnish
juice of 1/2 lime

Prep potatoes and wash them in running water to get rid of the excess starch. 

Heat the oil in a wok or saucepan over medium heat. 

Fry the cumin seeds till they splutter. Then add your onions with a pinch of salt to make sure they cook evenly. 

Once the onions have softened, add the ginger and garlic. Fry them for a couple of minutes. 

Add the powdered spices and fry for 30 seconds to a minute, ensuring they don't remain raw but don't burn either. 

Now add the tomatoes and cook until they become thick and there's a thin layer of oil on the surface.

Add the potatoes along with enough water just to cover them. Put the lid on the pan and cook on a low heat for 15 minutes or until the potatoes have cooked through but not overcooked. Otherwise they will break down and turn into mash.

Add the peas and cook for 3 to 4 minutes. 

Stir in the chopped coriander and lime juice and check for salt. Season to your liking and serve immediately, garnished with more fresh coriander. 

NOTES: 

1. Different potatoes can take less or more time to cook so keep checking and adapt the recipe as required. 

2. This curry freezes well but when reheated the potatoes break down, which is not necessarily a bad thing, it's still delicious! If you want chunks of potato, you could boil a few and add them to the reheated dish. 

Enjoy! 

#indian101 #indianfood #indianrecipes #food #recipe #potato #peas #curry #aloomatar #vegan

HOPPERS AT HOME: ROAST SWEET POTATO WITH CHICKPEA AND COCONUT CURRY 🍠🍛🥥🍛

Today's recipe is perfect for a cold January day. It's healthy, quick, vegan but yet packed with flavour and goodness. I often make this for a quick lunch, but it's equally comforting for dinner. 

If you don't like sweet potato, swap it with baked jacket potato, and if you want to make it a little more indulgent, grate over some mature cheddar before drizzling your favorite chili oil. It's so versatile! 🧀🌶️🥔

1 large sweet potato
2 tbsp coconut oil
1 tsp cumin seeds 
1 medium red onion, chopped 
1 tsp ginger, grated
1 tsp garlic, minced
10-12 curry leaves 
1 small green chilli, chopped
1 tbsp ground coriander powder
1 tsp red chilli powder 
1/2 tsp turmeric powder 
1.5 tbsp double concentrated tomato paste (or 3 very ripe tomatoes)
150ml thick coconut milk
300-400g boiled chickpeas 
Salt, to taste 
Kale leaves, to garnish

Scrub and wash your sweet potato thoroughly. Then dry and rub some coconut oil over it and roast for 30 to 40 minutes at 200° C. 

In the meantime, prepare your curry. 

Heat coconut oil in a saucepan over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds. 
Once they splutter, add the red onion with a pinch of salt to help it cook evenly. 

When the onions have softened, add the ginger and garlic and cook for 2 minutes. 

Then tip in all the dry spices, curry leaves and green chilli. Cook for a minute and then add the tomatoes. Fresh tomatoes will take longer to cook but tomato paste takes about 2 minutes.

Now add the chickpeas and cook them for 3 minutes until they are coated in all the spices. Add a splash of water and coconut milk and continue cooking till the curry is nice and thick. Serve over roast sweet potato. 🍠💯

🌿To make the crispy kale leaves, wash and dry the leaves before rubbing some oil over and roasting them at 180c for 15 mins. 

❄️Leftover curry can keep for days in the fridge and freezes well too. Make a big batch ahead and freeze it in portions so you're never more than 3 mins of prep away from a delicious meal.

Enjoy!

HOW TO MAKE PANEER? 🇮🇳🧀

This Indian cheese needs no introduction. It comes from the North of India but today you'll struggle to find a menu anywhere in India that doesn't have paneer on it. 

It's ridiculously easy to make at home and so versatile. Use it instead of feta, halloumi or ricotta. I add spices and herbs to my paneer to take it up to the next level, especially when simply pan fried in some ghee or brown butter. 

1 litre full fat milk (I use gold top milk in the UK or buffalos milk in India)
Juice of 1/2 lemon
2 tbsp greek yoghurt
Salt, to taste
Herbs and spices of your choice (optional). I use ground cumin, pepper and fresh coriander. 

Boil milk on a medium heat while stirring constantly so it doesn't form a skin on the surface. Take it off the heat once it has boiled for 2 minutes. 

Mix the lemon juice and yoghurt and tip it into the boiled milk. Stir and leave aside for 3-4 minutes. The milk will split and the whey should be a clear greenish colour. If it's still milky, add a little more lemon juice and warm it gently until clear. 

Once the milk has split fully, add a few cubes of ice as this stops it cooking further. 

Strain the whey through a sieve lined with a clean tea towel or cheese cloth. Now wash the curds gently to remove the sour flavour. Salt and spice them up with herbs and spices or leave them plain. 

Wrap up the curds tightly and sandwich between two surfaces. The paneer should be ready to use in about 20 minutes. 

⭐Tips⭐

Paneer can be frozen, but it changes texture. 

Homemade paneer can be crumblier than store bought because the latter often use more technical processes or stabilizers to firm it up. To prevent homemade paneer from breaking up in your gravy, you can lightly pan fry it before adding it to a sauce.

The leftover whey is packed with protein and really healthy. Mix it into bread doughs, curries, smoothies or drink it as is. 

Try using paneer instead of tofu, halloumi or feta. You can use the curds (before pressing in step 5) instead of ricotta. 

I can't wait to see what you make with paneer at home. 

Enjoy! 

#Indian101 #indianfood #indianrecipes #food #recipe #paneer #vegetarian #cheese #instafood

CURRY LEAVES 🌿

These are undoubtedly one of my top 5 ingredients in the kitchen. I couldn't live without a constant supply of fresh curry leaves, something so integral to so much of what we cook at home and @hopperslondon

Here are some tips to use curry leaves if you're not familiar with them:

🗑️If you've got dried curry leaves, drop them in the bin! They are nothing like the fresh stuff and are better left out than substituted for fresh leaves. 

❄️On the other hand, fresh leaves can be frozen. Get them into a zip locked bag and freeze flat. They might change texture and colour, but do retain their flavour. Add them to a dish straight out of the freezer. 

🫰🏽Back home these grow like weeds, but in the UK they often cost as much as gold! So don't bin the stalks and stems, they've got great flavour and can be boiled in stocks and sauces. Pick them out right at the end. 

👨🏽‍⚕️Curry leaves have a special place in Indian cooking and a whole host of health benefits in Ayurveda. They are antioxidants and rich in vitamins. I don't profess to know these benefits in detail, but am thrilled about them as it's just an excuse to use more! 

🍛Fried curry leaves are a great garnish for dishes, and adding some in to stir fries right at the end can amp up flavour to the next level. They are also an integral part of a lot of tarkas or tempering added to dals and dishes before serving. 

🍲I use them in chutneys, eggs, soups, currys, fries, biryanis, and so much more. 

Check out our Hoppers at Home series for some great recipes using them, and stay tuned for many more curry leaf recipes over the coming weeks.

What's your favourite way to cook with curry leaves?

INDIAN 101: PALAK PANEER 🌿🧀🇮🇳

Today's recipe is a home style Palak Paneer. There are hundreds of variations of this dish using different combinations of spices and greens. This is the version I grew up eating at home and is one of the simplest. It's great for the whole family and very healthy. Feel free to adapt the recipe using other greens. 

In the UK people usually refer to any green (mostly-spinach) Indian sauce as 'Saag', which simply means leafy green vegetable. It's like calling any pie a pie (and as we know there are many). In India there are many green curries from Mustard Greens (Sarson) to Fenugreek (Methi) and more. This recipe from North India uses Spinach (Palak) as the main ingredient. 

1.5 tbsp ghee
1 tsp cumin seeds
1 small red onion, finely chopped
1/2 tsp minced garlic
1 tsp minced ginger
1/3 tin of tomatoes (3 small ripe tomatoes) 
Large pinch of Kasoori Methi (dried Fenugreek Leaves), optional 
250g spinach leaves
1 green chilli 
250g paneer 
Fresh cream (single cream), to garnish (optional)
Salt, to taste. 

1. Heat the ghee in a pan over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds and once they splutter tip in the red onions with a pinch of salt. 

2. Once the onions have softened, add the ginger garlic and cook for about 2 minutes. 

3. Now add the tomatoes and kasoori methi and cook for about 3 to 4 minutes. Until the tomatoes have reduced by a third. 

4. Add spinach and cover the saucepan. People boil the spinach first, I prefer adding it fresh and preserving all the juices and nutrients. Cook the spinach until it just wilts in its own steam and juices. Take it off the heat and blitz everything with one green chilli. 

5. Once you have a smooth sauce, add it back to the pan. Warm up and check for seasoning, add water if you like it thinner. 

6. Cut and soak the paneer in boiling water for 10 minutes. This helps make storebought paneer a lot softer. You can skip this step if using homemade paneer. I add it to the sauce raw, but you can pan fry it if you like. 

Enjoy it with a simple roti (lots in my Indian Bread Series below).

KERALA EGG CURRY 🥚🍛🌶️🔥

Today in Hoppers at Home, our exec chef @chefrenjith_sarathchandran is making his famous Kerala Egg Curry. He tells me this is a dish he cooks for his family every weekend, and it disappears in seconds! It's ridiculously delicious, especially with a Malabar Parotta or Hopper to scoop up. 

You can replace the eggs with chicken or vegetables, but personally I don't think anything beats a perfectly soft boiled egg in this dish. 

6 eggs
2 tbsp coconut oil
1 tsp mustard seeds
4-5 green cardamoms
1/2 tsp fennel seeds
1 tsp minced garlic
1 tsp minced ginger 
1 green chilli 
1 medium red onion
10-12 curry leaves
1 tbsp coriander powder
1 tsp red chilli powder
1/2 tsp turmeric powder
1 large ripe tomato
150 ml coconut milk
Salt to taste
Chilli oil, to garnish

1. Boil the eggs for 6 minutes and then plunge into cold water to stop them cooking. Peel and keep ready for your curry.

2. Heat the coconut oil in a saucepan and add the mustard seeds to it. Once they splutter, add the cardamom, fennel seeds, ginger, garlic, chilli, onions and curry leaves with a hit of salt.

3. Cook for 3-4 minutes and add the remaining spices and cook for a further minute. 

4. Now add the tomato and cook until everything has broken down and come together into a thick paste. About 6 to 8 minutes. Let it down with some water and continue simmering. Finally add the coconut milk and eggs and simmer for a couple of minutes. 

5. Garnish with some chilli oil and serve with a hopper or bread. 

This is so good, we might bring it on as a special @hopperslondon next month! In the meantime, we hope you enjoy cooking it at home and stay tuned for many more similar recipes!
